newsitem.title: USA: 25th Iditarod starts with nod to tradition.
newsitem.headline: 25th Iditarod starts with nod to tradition.

text.p: Fifty-three mushers, including old-timers who competed in the first inaugural race in 1973, departed Anchorage on Saturday to start the 25th Iditarod Trail Sled Dog Race.
First out of the starting chute was Joe Redington, the 80-year-old founder of the grueling race, who led the Iditarod's ceremonial 20-mile (36 km) run to Eagle River.
Some of the loudest cheers were for top woman racer DeeDee Jonrowe, who is competing despite major injuries suffered in an auto wreck this winter.
She hugged her mother, Peggy Stout, before stepping on her sled for the first leg of the 1,150-mile (1,850 km) race to Nome.
"You can't help but be concerned, because I'm a mother. Mothers are always concerned," Stout said of her daughter's injuries. "She won't overstep her bounds -- at least that's what she promises."

Others competing for a share of the purse in excess of $400,000, include two-time winner Jeff King, two-time winner Martin Buser, 1995 winner Doug Swingley and perennial contenders Tim Osmar, Charlie Boulding and Bill Cotter.

Last to depart was veteran Ken Chase who took part in the first Iditarod in 1973. Asked how this year's race compared with the first Iditarod, he said laughing: "Lots of rules and lots of support. Lots of interest."
The first Iditarod started with little fanfare, without the crowds, colourful uniforms or the rock music that blared on Saturday from speakers at the starting line, he said.
"Now we have to do all this stuff, propaganda -- well, advertising, I guess," he said. "It's nice for the public, but it's hard for the dogs."
Although Alaska Natives dominated many of the early races, Chase, a 55-year-old Athabaskan Indian from the Yukon River village of Anvik, was one of only four Natives who started this year's Iditarod.

Emmitt Peters, an Athabaskan from the Yukon River village of Ruby who won the 1975 Iditarod, said the big financial investment now needed to take part in the race was a major factor inhibiting Alaska Natives from taking part.

In 1975, he said, he spent $3,500 on the race. Now it took at least $25,000 to $30,000 to put together a competitive team and people in Native villages did not have access to lucrative sponsorships, he added.
"You either have to live in Anchorage or Fairbanks to get a shot at it," Peters said.

The race clock and real competition will start on Sunday, when mushers begin their wilderness journey from the nearby town of Willow -- a slight variation from the normal route forced by an early thaw.
Last year, King won the race in nine days, five hours and 43 minutes, 13 seconds. Swingley holds the record of nine days, two hours, 42 minutes and 19 seconds.
